questions.text: In patients with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease, which of the following ocular complications is the most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most common ocular manifestation of Crohn’s disease is episcleritis.

Uveitis is associated with both Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of endophthalmitis in a patient following eye trauma?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis, followed by Bacillus cereus.

However, if the trauma involves soil contamination, Bacillus cereus is the most common cause of post-traumatic endophthalmitis.

questions.text: What is the most common testicular tumor in infants?
questions.solution:
Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age.

Prepubertal teratoma is the second most common testicular tumor in infants and children.

In adults, pure yolk sac tumor is rare. The yolk sac elements frequently occur in combination with embryonal carcinoma (as a mixed tumor).

Related Pearl: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma

questions.text: Which is the most common abdominal tumor seen in children?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is the most common abdominal tumor of childhood.

Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common primary malignant renal tumor of childhood.

The renal origin of the mass is usually apparent on CT, but it can be mistaken for neuroblastoma. Wilm's tumor shows peripheral calcification in contrast-enhanced CT, unlike intratumoral calcifications and vascular encasement, which are observed in neuroblastoma.

Features Wilms tumor (Nephroblastoma) Neuroblastoma
Age group Peaks at 3-4 years of age Age <2 years of age
Presentation Painless abdominal mass Painful abdominal mass
Associated syndromes

WAGR syndrome

Beckwith Weidman syndrome

Denys Drash syndrome

 Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome
Calcifications Uncommon (10-15%) Very common (90%)
Margins Well circumscribed Poorly marginated
Vascular invasion Extends into the IVC and renal vein Encases vascular structures but does not invade them
Metastasis Lung (most common) Bone (most common)
Findings on CECT Peripheral calcifications Intratumoral calcifications with vascular encasement

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with heat intolerance and weight loss for the past few weeks. He has lost 10 kgs despite having an increased appetite. On examination, he has a fine tremor of the hands, and his thyroid is enlarged. Lab investigations reveal low TSH and elevated T3 and T4. What is the most common ocular motility defect seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Grave's disease. The most common ocular motility defect seen in Grave's disease is elevator restriction.

It occurs due to the fibrotic contracture of the inferior rectus muscle. The inferior rectus muscle has to relax during the elevation of the eye. The fibrosis of the muscle restricts its relaxation and thus elevation of the eye is restricted.

There is an inability to look up (in both adducted and abducted positions) along with esotropia (fibrosis of the medial rectus). 

Only the belly of the muscle is involved in thyroid myopathy; the tendon is characteristically spared.

Ocular motility restriction in order of frequency is as follows:

  • Elevation defect
  • Abduction defect, due to fibrosis of the medial rectus
  • Depression defect, due to fibrosis of the superior rectus
  • Adduction defect, due to fibrosis of the lateral rectus

questions.text: What is the most common type of breech presentation?
questions.solution: Frank breech is the most common type of breech.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presented with fever, malaise, and painful enlargement of the thyroid gland after a few days following viral fever. On investigation, thyroid antibodies were normal and serum T4 was slightly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is suggestive of subacute granulomatous thyroiditis.

It is the most common cause of a painful thyroid. It is also known as painful subacute thyroiditis, de Quervain thyroiditis, or migratory thyroiditis (this is because the pain can shift to different locations in the thyroid). 

Option A: Subacute lymphocytic thyroiditis (postpartum thyroiditis) is typically painless. It often occurs after pregnancy and is characterized by lymphocytic inflammation in the thyroid.

Option B: Riedel's thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by a painless, rapidly growing thyroid mass with extensive fibrosis involving the thyroid and contiguous neck structures.

Option C: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that presents as painless enlargement of the thyroid associated with some degree of hypothyroidism in middle-aged women.

questions.text: What is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient regions?
questions.solution:
Follicular thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-deficient areas.

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid malignancy in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and radiation-exposed areas. 

Related Pearl: Thyroid Malignancy - Most Commons

  • Most common primary thyroid malignancy – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with radiation - Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine sufficient areas – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with amyloid - Medullary carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy associated with MEN 2 syndrome - Medullary carcinoma
  • Most aggressive thyroid malignancy with worst prognosis - Anaplastic carcinoma
  • Thyroid malignancy with best prognosis - Papillary carcinoma

questions.text: The most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children originates from _________
questions.solution:
The most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma, which usually arises from soft tissues such as muscle.

  • Most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children: Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Most common primary benign orbital tumor in adults: Cavernous hemangioma 
  • Most common primary malignant orbital tumor in adults: Lymphoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common end-product of fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
The most common end product of fatty acid synthesis is palmitic acid.

Palmitic acid is a 16 carbon saturated long chain fatty acid (LCFA). The substrate for its synthesis is acetyl CoA. Acetyl CoA is also the end product of fatty acid beta-oxidation.

questions.text: A CECT abdomen done to evaluate an elderly man with intermittent flank pain is shown below. Which of the following will be the most common site for secondary metastasis in patients with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The history and CECT mentioned in the above scenario are consistent with a diagnosis of renal cell carcinoma. The most common site for secondary metastasis in RCC is the lungs, where they form secondaries commonly known as cannonball secondaries.

The tumor is prone to extend into the renal vein and reach the lungs via circulation. RCC also metastasizes to the bone, lymph nodes, liver, adrenal glands, and brain.

Para-aortic nodes are the first draining lymph nodes.

The image below shows multiple round opacities in bilateral lungs suggestive of cannonball metastasis in the lungs.

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients one to four months following transplantation?
questions.solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

CMV is the most common virus to affect recipients after organ transplantation (kidney, heart, lung etc). The maximal risk occurs between 1 and 4 months after transplantation (in the absence of prophylaxis). The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients includes fever, leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. Antiviral prophylaxis with ganciclovir or valganciclovir is used in renal transplant recipients whenever indicated to prevent CMV disease. 

Given below are the most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients: 

Peritransplant (less than 1 month) Early (1-6 months) Late (more than 6 months)
  • Wound infection
  • Herpes virus
  • Oral candidiasis
  • Urinary tract infection
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Hepatitis B
  • Listeria
  • Aspergillus
  • Nocardia
  • BK Virus (polyoma)
  • Herpes Zoster

questions.text: You see a neonate undergoing phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia. Blood workup revealed the presence of a hemolytic picture along with spherocytes and polychromatophilic reticulocytes. MCV is low normal along with elevated MCHC. There was a similar history of hemolytic anemia in the mother. The pedigree analysis points towards an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The most likely genetic mutation seen in this case is?
questions.solution:
The Ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in the given case of autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis (HS).

Hemolytic manifestation causing indirect hyperbilirubinemia requiring phototherapy or blood transfusion in infancy with positive family history and typical laboratory findings is suggestive of HS.

History of blood transfusions in later life and not infancy is used to classify the severity of the disease.  

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS- autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal-dominant HS- ankyrin > Band 3
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal-recessive HS- spectrin
  • Most severe form of HS- spectrin (recessive) 

Classification of the severity of HS is based on the requirement of blood transfusion in later life and not during infancy.

RBC Membrane-Cytoskeleton disorders

Chromosomal Location

Protein Produced

Disease (Inheritance)

-alpha Spectrin

Stomatocytosis

Band 4.2

HS (recessive)

Abbreviations: HE, hereditary elliptocytosis; HS, hereditary spherocytosis

questions.text: What is the most common cause of polypoid cystitis?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of polypoid cystitis is indwelling catheters.

Polypoid cystitis is an inflammatory lesion resulting from mucosal irritation. It may also be associated with radiation therapy and malignant tumors. It usually involves the posterior wall of the bladder.

Grossly, it may show bulbous or papillary appearance and may be confused with papillary urothelial carcinoma. Microscopically, the papillary projections are broad-based, non-branching, and without atypia. Stroma is edematous with minimal inflammation.

Options A and D: Adenovirus infection and the use of anti-cancer drugs like cyclophosphamide cause hemorrhagic cystitis.

Option B: Systemic allergic disorders cause eosinophilic cystitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Cystitis

Type of cystitis Etiology Characteristic features
Interstitial cystitis Idiopathic Hunner's ulcer
Polypoid cystitis Catheterization of bladder Mimics malignancy
Malakoplakia Defective phagocytosis Michaelis– Gutmann bodies
Eosinophilic cystitis Systemic allergic disorders Submucosal eosinophils
Emphysematous cystitis Clostridium perfringens Associated with Diabetes
Follicular cystitis Prolonged urinary retention, intravesicular chemotherapy or BCG Lymphoid follicles within bladder mucosa
Hemorrhagic cystitis

Cyclo-phosphamide, BK virus, Adenovirus

 Prophylactic administration of mesna reduces the incidence

questions.text: Which of the following malignancies is most commonly associated with the paraneoplastic manifestation shown below?
questions.solution:
This image shows velvety warty hyperpigmentation on the front of the neck called acanthosis nigricans. By far, the commonest site of underlying neoplasm is the gastrointestinal tract (70–90%), and gastric adenocarcinoma is the most frequent.

Production by tumor cells of either transforming growth factor α (TGF-α) or cytokines that activate insulin‐like growth factors or their cutaneous receptors has been proposed as the pathogenetic mechanism.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

Skin condition Most commonly associated malignancy
Acanthosis nigricans Gastric adenocarcinoma
Acanthosis palmaris Bronchial carcinoma
Sign of LeserTrélat Gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma
Acquired-ichthyosis Hodgkin disease
Pityriasis rotunda Hepatocellular carcinoma
Paraneoplastic pigmentation Small cell bronchial carcinoma
Acrokeratosis paraneoplastica Squamous cell carcinoma of the upper respiratory or gastrointestinal
tracts
Erythema gyratum-repens Lung cancer
Necrolytic migratory erythema Glucagon secreting
pancreatic islet cell adenoma
Dermatomyositis Lung cancer in men, breast and gynaecological tumours in women and colorectal cancers in both sexes
Scleroderma‐like skin changes Carcinoid syndrome
Paraneoplastic pemphigus B‐cell proliferations and thymoma or thymoma‐like neoplasms; specifically Non Hodgkin's lymphoma (42%)
Dermatitis herpetiformis Lymphoma
Porphyria cutanea- tarda and variegate porphyrias Hepatocellular Carcinoma
Erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis Mycosis fungoides or Sézary syndrome
Pyoderma gangrenosum Hematological malignancy
Sweet syndrome Hematological malignancy
Migratory thrombo-phlebitis (Trousseau's syndrome) Carcinoma Pancreas

questions.text: In 40% of patients, this is the first sign of undiagnosed cancer. This finding in isolation is associated with which of the following internal malignancies?
questions.solution:
The image shows enhanced dermatoglyphics with thickened velvety palms that have the appearance of tripe, the stomach lining of beef. Tripe palms or acanthosis palmaris occurring alone is more often associated with bronchial carcinoma. 

Other sites of tumors are: 

  • Genitourinary tract
  • Carcinoma breast 

Acanthosis nigricans or sign of Leser-Trelat is most commonly associated with gastric carcinoma

The appearance or exacerbation of tripe palms in a known cancer patient may be a sign of recurrence of the malignancy.

The image below shows tripe palms.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

questions.text: The most common skin- related complaint reported in patients with HIV is _________.
questions.solution:
In the post-antiretroviral era, idiopathic pruritus has become the most common skin-related disease manifestation reported in patients with HIV.

The other common skin manifestations are:

  • Xerosis (23%) and icythyosis
  • Nodular prurigo
  • Folliculitis
  • Eosinophilic folliculitis
  • Pruritic papular eruption
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis (9%)
  • Granuloma annulare
  • Drug eruptions
  • Herpes simplex
  • Herpes zoster
  • Viral warts
  • Mollusca
  • Oral and vaginal candidosis
  • Tinea (including onychomycosis)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents with a history of fatigue, dark-coloured urine and photosensitivity. He consumes alcohol regularly. On examination, hyperpigmentation and scarring are present on the face and dorsum of the hand. Lab findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 7.4 mg/dl
Peripheral blood picture: Suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anaemia
Urinary porphobilinogen level: Normal
Urinary uroporphyrin level: Increased
questions.solution:
A middle-aged adult presenting with features of hemolysis and photosensitivity with elevated urine uroporphyrin suggests a diagnosis of porphyria cutanea tarda.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common porphyria. It is caused by the deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III.  It is characterized by photosensivity, which manifests as blistering skin lesions on the back of the hands with crusting and scarring. It is associated with hemochromatosis and patients may develop chronic liver disease. There is increased excretion of uroporphyrin in the urine.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

(XLDPP)

(ALADP)

(ALAD)

Acute intermittent porphyria
(AIP)

(Uroporphyrin I synthase)

Periodic abdominal pain, peripheral neuropathy, psychiatric symptoms, tachycardia
Congenital Erythropoietic porphyria
(CEP)
Uroporphyrinogen III synthase
(UROS)
 Increased urinary, fecal and red cell uroporphyrin I Cutaneous photosensitivity
Severe photosensitivity with erythema, swelling and blistering, hemolytic anemia, splenomegaly
Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT)

(UROD)

(HCP)

(CPOX)

(VP)

(PPOX)

(EPP)

(FECH)

Most porphyrias are autosomal dominant except:
  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria
  • Congenital erythropoietic porphyria
  • Erythropoietic protoporphyria
  • X-linked protoporphyria

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common symptom of ADHD?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of ADHD is hyperactivity.

The most cited characteristics of children with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), in order of frequency, are as follows:

  • Hyperactivity (fidgety, unable to sit still, as though driven by a motor, hyper-talkative, interrupts, blurts out answers)
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility, perseveration, failure to finish tasks, inattention, poor concentration)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organization, jumping up in class)
  • Memory and thinking deficits. Intellectual disability is not seen in ADHD.
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits

questions.text: What is the most common skeletal anomaly associated with Klippel-Feil syndrome?
questions.solution:
Most common skeletal anomaly associated with Klippel-Feil syndrome is scoliosis. 

Klippel-Feil syndrome is often associated with other skeletal and extraskeletal anomalies: 

  • Skeletal anomalies: scoliosis > Sprengel deformity > cervical ribs
  • Extraskeletal anomalies: renal abnormalities > deafness > congenital heart disease

Ventricular septal defect is the most common cardiovascular anomaly associated with this syndrome.

Synkinesis (mirror movements) is involuntary paired movements of hands and arms seen in around 20% of children with Klippel-Feil syndrome. The child cannot move one hand without a similar reciprocal movement in the opposite hand.

questions.text: A 15-year old boy comes to the clinic complaining about recurrent painful oral ulcers. He also experiences repeated episodes of eye redness and pain which subside with medication. On examination, ulcers are seen on his genitals. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Behçet disease. Nail fold capillary abnormalities are typically seen in systemic sclerosis.

Behcet disease is a neutrophilic vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels that classically presents as a clinical triad of recurrent oral aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis. Other skin findings include erythema nodosa (red tender nodules on legs) and positive pathergy test (pustular reaction 24-48 hrs after sterile needle puncture or normal saline injection).

There can also be gastrointestinal and pulmonary manifestations, with disease mortality related to severe neurologic involvement or rupture of vascular aneurysms. Dural sinus thrombosis is the most common CNS manifestation in children. Pulmonary aneurysms are the most severe feature of pediatric BD.

It is associated with HLA subtype B51. T helper 17 (Th17) cells play an important contribution in the recruitment of neutrophils, which will later infiltrate into the vessel wall.

Related Pearl: HLA association with diseases

Autoimmune Gut and Skin Diseases and HLA associations
Gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease) DQ2 , DQ8
Chronic active hepatitis DR3
Dermatitis herpetiformis DR3
SLE(white) DR3
Sjogren’s syndrome DR3
Psoriasis vulgaris Cw6
Pemphigus vulgaris DR4, DQ1
Bullous pemphigoid variant DQ7
Autoimmune Endocrine Diseases and HLA associations  
Type 1 diabetes mellitus DQ8, DR4, DR3, DR2
Hyperthyroidism (Graves’) B8, DR3
Hyperthyroidism (Japanese) B35
Adrenal insufficiency DR3
Autoimmune Neurologic Diseases and HLA associations  
Myasthenia gravis B8

 Other Important Diseases and their HLA Associations  

Ankylosing Spondylitis

Reactive Arthritis

Psoriatic Arthritis

 Hashimoto thyroiditis DR3, DR5

questions.text: The most widely used illegal drug in the world is _______.
questions.solution:
Cannabis is the most widely used illegal drug in the world.

Cannabis is the fourth most commonly used psychoactive drug among adults in the United States, after caffeine, alcohol, and nicotine.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Nodular sclerosis is the most common type of Hodgkin's lymphoma, while mixed cellularity is most common in India.

The incidence of nodular sclerosis is equal in men and women. It commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes. It commonly affects adolescents and young adults. It has an excellent prognosis.

Mixed-cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma is seen in patients older than 50 years of age. There is a male predominance.

The image given below shows the histology of nodular sclerosis showing a lacunar variant of Reed–Sternberg cells

questions.text: A college student presents to the dermatology OPD with a pruritic lesion on his left foot for 5 days. Which is the most common causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution: The above image shows a scaly pruritic lesion of tinea pedis or ringworm of foot is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum infections (70%) followed by Trichophyton interdigitale infections (15%), Epidermophyton floccosum infections (<10%), and mixed infections (5%).

questions.text: What is the most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV?
questions.solution:
Western blot is the most commonly used confirmatory test for HIV. It detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env. Western blot has a high specificity and is therefore hence used as a confirmatory test.

In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests.

Drawbacks include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

questions.text:
A sexually active woman presents with multiple lesions over her genital region as shown below. Which of the following organisms are implicated in this condition?
  1. HPV 16 
  2. HPV 11
  3. HPV 18
  4. HPV 6 
  5. HPV 31
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image are suggestive of genital warts. Human papillomavirus (HPV) 6 and 11 cause nearly all genital warts.

It is usually clinically diagnosed but if co-existing neoplasia is suspected then a biopsy is required. HPV serotyping is not required for routine diagnosis.

questions.text: Mutations causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are most commonly seen in the gene encoding which of the following?
questions.solution:
Mutations causing hypertrophic cardiomyopathy are most commonly seen in the genes encoding β-myosin heavy chain (β-MHC).

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is an autosomal dominant disease. In the majority of cases it is due to missense mutations in the following two sarcolemmal protein genes: 

  • Myosin binding protein C (MYBC)
  • Beta myosin heavy chain (MYH7)

questions.text: The most common site of pseudoaneurysms in chronic pancreatitis is _______.
questions.solution:
The most common site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis is splenic artery > gastroduodenal artery > pancreaticoduodenal artery.

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein 

M/C site of pseudoaneurysm in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic artery

questions.text: What is the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals?
questions.solution:
Tuberculosisis the most common opportunistic infection in HIV-infected individuals globally and in India.

In patients with relatively high CD4+ T cell counts, the typical pattern of pulmonary reactivation occurs (60–80%). In patients with lower CD4+ T cell counts, disseminated disease is seen.

Primary prophylaxis: Isoniazid and pyridoxine for 9 months for HIV-infected individuals meeting the following conditions:

  • PPD skin-test reaction of >5 mm or,
  • Positive IFN-γ release assay or,
  • Close household contacts of persons with active tuberculosis

questions.text: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia most commonly presents as _______.
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most commonly presents as female pseudohermaphroditism as the most common enzyme deficiency is 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia resembles a male's.

The image below shows ambiguous genitalia in a female with CAH:

The mechanism underlying the endocrine defects in 21-hydroxylase deficiency is depicted in the image below:

Babies with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present around 10-14 days of age with the subset of symptoms due to aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency and androgen excess.

Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises marked by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis.

Cortisol deficiency causes manifestations like hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.

Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency results in virilization of females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.

Without treatment, shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency resulting in incomplete virilization. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency is 2nd most common enzyme affected in CAH.

Option C: True hermaphroditism is presently referred to as an ovotesticular disorder of sex development(DSD). Here, both ovarian and testicular tissue is present. It is not due to CAH.

Option D: 46 XY intersex (now called 46 XY DSD) has under virilization of genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency,  17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, and not 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: The most common subtype of fibromuscular dysplasia is ______.
questions.solution:
Most common type of fibromuscular dysplasia is medial fibroplasia.

Histological subtypes of fibromuscular dysplasia

  • Intimal fibroplasia (focal)
  • Medial dysplasia (multifocal)
  • Adventitial hyperplasia

Medial dysplasia is of further 3 types

  • Medial fibroplasia
    • Most common type and characterized by alternating areas of thinned media and fibromuscular ridges.
  • Medial hyperplasia 
  • Perimedial dysplasia

questions.text: With respect to the condition shown in image, select the most appropriate response.

choices.text: Most common nephropathy associated with malignancy
Equal incidence  in males and females
Associated with antibodies against Megalin antigen in humans.

questions.solution:
The given immunofluorescence image shows diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3 which is characteristic of membranous glomerulonephritis (membranous nephropathy). It is the most common nephropathy associated with malignancy.

Membranous glomerulonephritis

  • It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in the elderly.
  • Most common nephropathy associated with malignancy.
  • The highest incidence of renal vein thrombosis.
  • Light microscopy shows uniform thickening of the basement membrane along with peripheral capillary loops. 
  • Immunofluorescence shows diffuse granular deposits of IgG and C3.

Other options:

Option b: Male to female ratio is 2:1

Option c: Electron microscopy shows subepithelial deposits (not subendothelial deposits)

Option d:  Associated with antibodies against M-type phospholipase A2 receptor on human podocytes (antibodies against Megalin are present in rats, not in humans)

 

The granular deposits have been demarcated in the immunofluorescence image below. 

The subeipthelial dposits are marked in the electron microcopic image below.

questions.text: A 27-year-old sexually active man presents to the OPD with the following finding. He informs you that a few days ago, he developed an erythematous vesicular lesion at the same location within hours of taking a drug. Which of the following is most commonly implicated here?
questions.solution:
The characteristic lesion healing with hyperpigmentation following drug intake is consistent with fixed drug eruption. NSAIDs are the most commonly implicated drug. 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE) is a cutaneous adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent well‐defined lesions occurring at the same sites each time the offending drug is taken. It typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

The most common drugs that act as triggers are:

  1. NSAIDs (25%)
  2. Paracetamol (15%)
  3. Cotrimoxazole
  4. Tetracyclines

FDE is a form of classical delayed‐type hypersensitivity reaction.

Typically, FDE presents as a sharply defined, round, or oval erythematous and oedematous plaque, which evolves to become dusky, violaceous, and occasionally vesicular or bullous lesions. Lesions are usually solitary or few in number.

Commonly affected sites include the lips, genitals, palms, and soles; 5% of cases may have an exclusive mucosal involvement. Overall, the most common site involved is the genitalia.

The majority of FDE is self‐limiting with an excellent prognosis.

Note: The generalized bullous form of FDE should be differentiated from toxic epidermal necrolysis by prior similar history, absence of target lesions, and no involvement of mucosal surfaces.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for fixed drug eruption?
questions.solution:
Glans penis is the best answer among the given options. Fixed drug eruptions(FDE) can occur anywhere in the body. However, 50% of FDE occurs in the genital and oral mucosa. The other common sites are palms and soles.

Drug‐specific clinical patterns have been reported. These include the following:

  • NSAID‐induced FDE - genitals and lips
  • Tetracycline and trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole‐induced FDE - genitals
  • Metamizole‐induced FDE - trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine‐induced FDE - face

The image below shows hyperpigmentation on the glans penis- healed fixed drug eruption.

questions.text: What is the isotype of the rheumatoid factor most commonly measured in the laboratory?
questions.solution:
IgM isotype is the rheumatoid factor (RF) most commonly measured in laboratories.

IgM RF has been found in 75–80% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. IgG and IgA isotypes of RF have also been identified.

However, RF is not specific for rheumatoid arthritis and can also be found in the following conditions:

  • Primary Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Subacute bacterial endocarditis
  • Hepatitis B and C

questions.text: What is the most common cause of vasculitis in children in India?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of vasculitis in children in India is Kawasaki disease.

Kawasaki disease has a higher incidence in children in the Indian subcontinent.

The most common vasculitis worldwide is Henoch-Schonlein purpura, whereas in the Indian subcontinent and other Asian countries the most common vasculitis is Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: The most common site for chondrosarcoma is ______.
questions.solution:
The most common site for chondrosarcoma is the proximal femur.

Other sites of involvement are long bones of upper limbs > pelvis> the ribs.

questions.text: What is the most common type of renal tubular acidosis?
questions.solution:
The most common type of renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is the type 4 or hyperkalemic type.

Related Pearl: Characteristics of renal tubular acidosis (RTA)

questions.text: What is the most common developmental abnormality of the uterus?
questions.solution:
The most common developmental abnormality of the uterus is septate uterus, followed by bicornuate uterus.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text: Which of the following ovarian tumors is the most radiosensitive?
questions.solution: Dysgerminoma is the most radiosensitive ovarian tumor. They are highly susceptible to radiotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common viral cause of diarrhea in adults?
questions.solution:
The most common viral cause of diarrhoea in adults (and overall) is norovirus (Norwalk virus).

In children, the most common cause is rotavirus.

questions.text: Following road traffic accident, a man developed head injury resulting in a defect in the association fibres. Which of the following is not classified under these fibres?
questions.solution:
Corona radiata is not classified under association fibers. It an example of projection fiber.

Option A: Cingulum is a long association fiber connecting the frontal and parietal lobes with the parahippocampal and temporal cortical region.

Option C: Fornix is an example of association fiber but only Hippocampal commissure of fornix is a commisural fibre as it has transverse fibers connecting the two crura of the fornix.

Option D: Arcuate fasciculus is a short association fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Which is the most common benign cause of pyometra?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of pyometra is senile endometritis.

Pyometra refers the collection of pus in the uterus. The most common cancer that causes pyometra is carcinoma cervix followed by carcinoma endometrium.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with recurrent duodenal ulcers with poor response to medical therapy. He had a history of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection. Which among the following is the next appropriate step?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger Ellison syndrome (ZES). The next appropriate step to evaluate the patients for ZES is by measuring the serum gastrin levels. History of hyperparathyroidism and transsphenoidal prolactinoma resection indicates MEN1 syndrome. ZES is commonly associated with MEN1.

The normal gastrin levels are <150 pg/mL. An increase of >10 times the normal levels is highly suggestive of ZES.

Secretin test is a gastrin provocative test. It is done when the gastrin levels and the acid secretory studies are inconclusive for ZES. It is the most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma.

Endoscopic ultrasound is done to localize the tumor. It is done after the diagnosis of ZES has been established.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 70-year-old presented with a lesion over the vulva as shown below. Bilateral inguinal lymph nodes were palpable. Biopsy of the lesion revealed cells containing large, pleomorphic nuclei. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is the 2nd most common vulval cancer
The most common site is clitoris
It may arise from a  junctional naevus
Radical vulvectomy with bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment

questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of vulval melanoma. The most commonly involved site is labia majora followed by labia minora and clitoris.

Vulval melanoma is the second most common vulval cancer. It may arise from junctional naevus. It has a high propensity for local and distant recurrence and has a poor prognosis. 

Radical vulvectomy and bilateral regional lymphadenectomy is the preferred treatment.

questions.text: The most common cause of infectious esophagitis in a non-immunocompromised patient is _________.
questions.solution:
The most common causes of infectious esophagitis in a non-immunocompromised patient are 

  • Herpes simplex virus
  • Candida albicans
Immunocompromised
  1. Candida species
  2. Herpes simplex virus
  3. Cytomegalovirus
Non- immunocompromised
  1. Herpes simplex virus
  2. Candida albicans

questions.text: A 10-month-old female is brought to the clinic with a 102° F fever for 2 days. The mother says that she also cries during urination. The history is significant for similar episodes in the past which were treated with antibiotics. Urine analysis shows nitrite-positivity and gram-negative bacteria are seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following anomaly is most commonly associated with this child's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent urinary tract infection. The most common anomaly associated with this condition in children is vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).

VUR usually is congenital and often familial. It is more common in females. It occurs when the submucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent.

The image below shows VUR grading

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a newborn baby girl sent on day 2 of life shows mild hemolysis. What is the most common cause of this finding in a newborn?
questions.solution:
ABO incompatibility is the most common cause of hemolytic disease of newborns and affects the firstborn. It is usually mild and subclinical.

This incompatibility between the mother and fetus generally results in milder disease than Rh incompatibility does. 

It arises when a mother with blood group type O becomes pregnant with a fetus of different blood type (A/B). The mother's serum contains naturally occurring anti-A and anti-B, which can cross the placenta and cause hemolysis of fetal RBCs.

Although antibodies against A and B factors occur without previous immunization (natural antibodies), they are usually IgM, which do not cross the placenta. However, IgG antibodies to A antigen may be present, and these do cross the placenta, resulting in A-O iso-immune hemolytic disease in the first-born infant (A-O is more common than B-O).

questions.text: A 5th standard girl is brought to the OPD with a high fever and cough with expectoration for 3 days. Her chest X-ray shows multiple pneumatoceles. Which of the following is the most common etiological agent implicated in this presentation?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia manifests as confluent bronchopneumonia, which is often unilateral and characterized by the presence of hemorrhagic necrosis and irregular areas of cavitation of the lung parenchyma, resulting in pneumatoceles, empyema, or at times, bronchopulmonary fistulas. 

The following CT image shows cavitating pneumonia by S. aureus:

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant with seizures and failure to thrive has cutaneous nodules and hepatosplenomegaly. On investigations, CBC reveals hyperleukocytosis with a leukocyte count of 1,10,000cells/mm3. Peripheral smear and immunophenotyping studies reveal large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker. On a cytogenetic study which of the following is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The above findings are diagnostic of Infantile acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Translocation (4;11) involving the MLL gene is most commonly associated with Infantile leukemia accounts for the very high relapse rate.

2% of cases of leukemia during childhood occur before the age of 1 year and are referred to as infantile leukemia.

Patients often present with hyperleukocytosis and extensive tissue infiltration producing organomegaly. Subcutaneous nodules, known as leukemia cutis, caused by infiltration by leukemic cells are observed more often in infants than in older children. 

The leukemic cell morphology is usually that of large, irregular lymphoblasts, with a phenotype negative for the CD10 (common ALL antigen) marker (pro-B), unlike most older children with B-ALL, who are CD10 +. Has a very poor prognosis.

Note:

Infants with AML present with CNS and skin involvement and most commonly have a subtype known as acute myelomonocytic leukemia.
